name: 2,2,3-trimethyl-3-pentanol
source: Wilhoit R. C. Physical and Thermodynamic Properties of Aliphatic Alcohols. (Supplement to Journal of Physical and Chemical Reference Data; Vol 2; No. 1.); American Chemical Society; Washington; 1973.

name: 2,2,3-trimethyl-3-pentanol
source: Wilhoit R. C. Physical and Thermodynamic Properties of Aliphatic Alcohols. (Supplement to Journal of Physical and Chemical Reference Data; Vol 2; No. 1.); American Chemical Society; Washington; 1973.
Reason: The basic unit for 2,2,3-trimethyl-3-pentanol can be considered butanol, with a melting point of around -90°C. Each methyl group typically raises the melting point by 20-30°C due to increased molecular weight and van der Waals interactions. However, the hydroxyl group (OH) significantly increases the melting point due to hydrogen bonding, which is typically a bigger effect than alkyl groups. The steric hindrance of the additional methyl groups in this compound, especially at the 3-position, hinder the efficacy of hydrogen bonding, thus counteracting the increase due to the hydroxyl group. As there are three extra methyl groups, the predicted change in melting point is (+20-30°C per methyl group) - (decreased hydrogen bonding efficiency).
